Description: Fragment of a hard green mottled black pebble, with very polished surface; stone identified as serpentine on the Ashmolean database; pierced through thickness at top; maybe used as an amuletic pendant or as a weight for fishing-net (less likely); only upper part preserved.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Other similar pendants were discovered in Naukratis: Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 11.45987; BM 1886,0401.1724. According to Petrie, such pendant had some amuletic properties and were worn as forehead pendants, in burial contexts; the examples are however dated to the Prehistoric and modern period (Petrie 1914, 29, pl. XVI no. 130). It is uncertain if Naukratis examples had similar function and context of discovery. Petrie, W.M.F. 1914, Amulets, London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.398) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
